My reasoning:
• The theatre interior has a distinctive presidential box draped in American flags with a portrait – closely resembling the box where President Abraham Lincoln was assassinated.  
• That box is inside Ford’s Theatre in Washington, D.C., USA.  
• Ford’s Theatre’s street address (511 10th St NW) has coordinates very near 38.8966 N, –77.0259 W.

{
    "lat": 38.8966,
    "lon": -77.0259,
    "city": "Washington",

Reasoning:
1. The building in the centre is a two-storey gabled sandstone structure with small barred windows and a “C • R” cartouche – typical of early 19th-century convict-era government buildings in Australia.
2. Behind it, the classical sandstone building with a colonnade resembles the Lands Administration Building of Queensland, and the very tall blue-glass tower further back matches Brisbane’s 1 William Street.
3. The only surviving convict storehouse in Brisbane is the Commissariat Store Museum, located at 115 William Street, beside the river and below the Lands Administration Building.
4. The landscaped stairs in the foreground align with the new Queen’s Wharf riverside park that now fronts the Commissariat Store.

This places the camera on the Queen’s Wharf pedestrian area, looking east-north-east at the Commissariat Store in Brisbane, Australia.

Final answer:
{
    "lat": -27.4720,
    "lon": 153.0223,
    "city": "Brisbane",
    "country": "Australia"
}

My thinking process:

• In front of it is the department-store building “Galeria Kaufhof,” located on Alexanderplatz in central Berlin.  
• Thus the spot is Alexanderplatz, Berlin, Germany.  
• Approximate coordinates for the front of the Galeria Kaufhof Alexanderplatz building are about 52.5214° N, 13.4142° E.

{

}

The shop window shows the name “Soieries Lyonnaises” (“Lyon Silks”), a clear reference to Lyon’s historic silk-making industry.  
The architecture – stone arch doorway, narrow pastel-colored buildings reflected in the glass, and the small terracotta-tiled pedestrian street – is typical of Vieux-Lyon (the Old Town) on the west bank of the Saône River. This neighbourhood is filled with small silk and textile boutiques catering to tourists.

Therefore, the scene is almost certainly in Vieux-Lyon, France. An approximate central point for the silk-shop area along Rue Saint-Jean / Rue du Bœuf is:

45.7632 ° N, 4.8276 ° E.

{
    "lat": 45.7632,
    "lon": 4.8276,
    "city": "Lyon",
    "country": "France"
}

Reasoning:

- Additional U.S. sports and hip-hop memorabilia fit well with Atlanta’s strong cultural connection to both music and sports.
- No evidence in the image contradicts an Atlanta location, and no other city is as closely tied to both the 1996 Olympics and Coca-Cola.

Best conclusion: the photo was taken in Atlanta, Georgia, USA.

{
    "lat": 33.7490,
    "lon": -84.3880,

}

The picture is clearly taken from one of the rooftops of Souq Waqif, looking east-southeast toward the Fanar and the city skyline.

My reasoning:

• The vegetation (palm trees, Mediterranean shrubbery) and bright, dry light point to a warm Mediterranean climate.  
• The skyline in the distance includes a tall, narrow, beige grain-silo–like building with a jagged top.  This structure closely resembles the historic flour-mill / grain-silo on HaRakevet Street in south-central Tel-Aviv, adjacent to the linear “Park HaMesila” that follows the old Jaffa–Jerusalem railway right-of-way.  
• Park HaMesila features several modern red steel sculptures by Israeli artists; the one in the photograph (a tilted red square with a circular cut-out and parallel bars) is located on the park’s main path a short distance east of the silo building.  
• Therefore the spot is in Park HaMesila, Tel-Aviv, Israel, just south-east of the old train-station complex (“HaTahanah”) and north-west of the flour mill.

Approximate coordinates of the sculpture: 32.0545 °N, 34.7640 °E.

JSON answer:  
{
    "lat": 32.0545,
    "lon": 34.7640,
    "city": "Tel Aviv",
    "country": "Israel"
}

3. The mall interior – light tiles in large geometric panels, new ceilings and lighting – matches photographs of the recently renovated Great World City mall in Singapore, where motherswork occupies unit #02-117 (Level 2).

Hence the picture was taken inside Great World City, Singapore.

Thought process:
• The image shows an un-stitched 3-piece ladies’ suit (shirt piece, dupatta, trouser piece) that is typical of Pakistani “lawn” fabric collections released every summer.  
• The printed insert at lower left says “AMBROSIA – Digital Printed Embroidered Lawn Shirt / Digital Printed … Lawn Dupatta”. “Lawn” is a term overwhelmingly used in Pakistan for this light cotton.  
• “Ambrosia” is a collection name used by Pakistani textile company Al-Zohaib and sold widely across the country.  
• Such lawn collections are designed and photographed mainly in Lahore, the heart of Pakistan’s textile/fashion industry, where most big brands (including Al-Zohaib) have their head offices and studios.  
• Nothing in the photo points to another specific city, so Lahore is the most plausible single location.

Answer (best guess):

{
    "lat": 31.5204,
    "lon": 74.3587,
    "city": "Lahore",
    "country": "Pakistan"
}

Reasoning

2. St Ann’s Passage is a short covered arcade linking King Street with St Ann’s Square in the centre of Manchester, England.  
3. The shops visible (Hancocks jewellers on the left and Loake shoemakers on the right) are both found at this exact arcade entrance on King Street.
4. Therefore the photo was taken on King Street at the entrance to St Ann’s Passage / Old Exchange Buildings, Manchester.

Estimated co-ordinates for that doorway (checked on mapping tools) are about 53.4820 N, -2.2445 W.

Answer (JSON)

    "lon": -2.2445,
    "city": "Manchester",

}

Reasoning:
• The inscription on the monument is in Cyrillic, pointing to a Slavic country.  
• The white wall with a green metal coping and the glimpse of a large grey‐white colonnaded building behind it closely match the view from inside St. Michael’s Golden-Domed Monastery in Kyiv, where one can see the Ukrainian Ministry of Foreign Affairs over the monastery wall.  
• Inside the monastery grounds there is a granite cross-shaped sculpture commemorating the victims of the Holodomor; its shape (a cross cut-out with a stylised mother and child silhouette) is identical to the one in the photo.  

Therefore, the location is the courtyard of St. Michael’s Golden-Domed Monastery, Kyiv, Ukraine.

{
    "lat": 50.4550,
    "lon": 30.5270,

2. DIPT’s physical shop has for many years been at 819 Hornby Street in downtown Vancouver, on the east side of Hornby between Robson and Smithe Streets (across from the Vancouver Art Gallery).
3. The architecture in the photo—recessed entrance under a dark concrete overhang, small security camera, narrow retail frontage—matches the façade of the Hornby-Street location.
4. A little sticker that says “VanCity” (Vancouver’s credit-union brand) further supports that the picture is in Vancouver, Canada.

Coordinates of 819 Hornby St. are approximately 49.2819 N,  −123.1193 W.

• The flag on the tower appears to be the New Zealand flag (dark blue with Union Jack in the canton and red stars).

• A black event board at ground level contains the word “Aotea…”, hinting at Aotea Square, the main civic square of Auckland.

• The overall architecture, the corner tower, and its position next to Aotea Square exactly match Auckland Town Hall on Queen Street in the Auckland CBD.

Reasoning
• All the writing on the shop-fronts (“Brama wjazdowa – NIE ZASTAWIAĆ”, “Bielizna”, “Rajstopy”, “Pon-Pt”) is in Polish, so the scene is in Poland.  
• The car’s licence plate has the Polish EU strip and begins with the letters “WF”.  Polish registration prefixes that start with “W” are for Warsaw; “WF” is one of the Warsaw series.  
• The architecture (post-war concrete façade with black ceramic tiling on the ground floor) and the old-town style stone setts in the roadway match many small side streets in the central Śródmieście district of Warsaw.  
• One of the visible stores carries the URL “raj-stopy.com.pl”, which is a small hosiery/lingerie shop located in central Warsaw (Śródmieście).  Next door is an “R-kom.pl” computer / GSM shop that is likewise situated in the same area.

Putting these clues together, the photo is very likely taken on a downtown Warsaw side street, a few hundred metres south-west of the city centre (around the Hoża / Wilcza / Marszałkowska vicinity).  The centre-point of that cluster is at roughly:

Latitude 52.229° N  
Longitude 21.012° E

Final answer (best estimate)

    "lon": 21.012,
    "city": "Warsaw",

}

This building is a Gothic cathedral that was later converted into a mosque.  
Its façade has three pointed-arch portals and a large Gothic rose window, and two minarets stand where the original bell-towers once were.  
A string of lights (mahya) is hung between the minarets, a common feature in Turkish or Ottoman-style mosques.

Among the famous Gothic cathedrals converted to mosques in Cyprus, two stand out:

1. Lala Mustafa Pasha Mosque (former St Nicholas Cathedral) in Famagusta – but that building today has only one minaret.
2. Selimiye Mosque (former St Sophia Cathedral) in Nicosia – which retains two symmetrical minarets on its façade.

Because the photo clearly shows two minarets, the building is the Selimiye Mosque in the walled city of Nicosia (Lefkoşa) in Northern Cyprus.

Approximate coordinates of the Selimiye Mosque are about 35.1758 °N, 33.3631 °E.

{
    "lat": 35.1758,
    "lon": 33.3631,
    "city": "Nicosia",
    "country": "Cyprus"
}

Given its fixed street address (140 Dinso Rd, Sao Chingcha, Phra Nakhon, Bangkok 10200), the map coordinates are approximately 13.753 ° N, 100.499 ° E.

The twin neoclassical pavilions with Doric columns and golden rosettes are characteristic of the Ratinger Tor, a former city gate that marks an entrance to the Hofgarten in Düsseldorf, Germany. The Ratinger Tor consists of two small, temple-like guardhouses flanking the street “Heinrich-Heine-Allee / Maximilian-Weyhe-Allee.” The style, details, and surrounding greenery match well with this location, which is part of the UNESCO-listed ensemble “Palaces and Parks of Potsdam and Berlin” (hence the World Heritage plaque visible on the right-hand building).

Approximate coordinates for Ratinger Tor are about 51.2295° N latitude and 6.7775° E longitude.

{
    "lat": 51.2295,
    "lon": 6.7775,
    "city": "Düsseldorf",
    "country": "Germany"

The building in the photo is unmistakably Casa Batlló, one of Antoni Gaudí’s most famous works. Characteristic clues:

• Dragon-scale roof with a spine-like ridge.  
• Bone-shaped balconies and organic window frames, typical Gaudí style.  
• Overall mosaic façade with colorful trencadís tiles.  
• A turret topped by a cross.

Casa Batlló stands on Passeig de Gràcia in Barcelona’s Eixample district. Its well-known coordinates are roughly 41.3916° N, 2.1649° E.

{
    "lat": 41.3916,
    "lon": 2.1649,
    "city": "Barcelona",
    "country": "Spain"
}

– The surrounding architecture (mid-rise beige apartment blocks and a glassy high-rise), the yellow Israeli licence plates, and the Mediterranean vegetation are all consistent with Tel Aviv’s Kokhav Ha-Tzafon area.

My reasoning:

Reasoning:

1. Architecture: Mid-20th-century three-storey apartment blocks, rendered in pastel colours with small basement windows and simple rectangular window openings. This style is very common in Central Europe (especially former Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Poland, parts of Germany and Austria).

2. Paving: The walkway is made of small rectangular concrete pavers laid in a herring-bone pattern. That again is standard for Central-European housing estates.

3. Cars: A closer look (zooming in) shows licence-plates that are white with a narrow blue stripe on the left and a black font consisting of two letters, a hyphen and four digits (e.g. “XX-1234”). That exact typography matches the Czech Republic. Slovak plates have two letters + three numbers + two letters; Polish plates begin with one letter followed by four or five digits/letters; Hungarian plates have three letters + three digits with a hyphen. This therefore is almost certainly the Czech Republic.

4. Sign on the building: The small red-outlined street-plate next to the door is the classic style used in Prague (and most Czech cities): white text on a red background with a thin white border. It appears to read something like “…str.” and below a district number (again typical of Prague street plates). The building also has a small cream/blue corner – that is quite common in Prague’s 1920-30s “Bubeneč / Dejvice” workers’ housing estates.

5. Environment: The courtyard with tall narrow Lombardy poplars is common in Prague inner suburbs. The apartment blocks opposite (light beige 4-storey plus attic with shallow hip roof) are also classic Prague post-war infill.

6. The garages in the background (row garages) look identical to the ones behind the apartment blocks in Dejvice/Bubeneč (Prague 6), in the grid of streets between Jugoslávských partyzánů and the River Vltava.

Given all this, the most reasonable pinpoint is Prague, Czech Republic, in the residential estates of Dejvice/Bubeneč (roughly 50.107° N, 14.411° E).
